questions.text: A young lady who presented with oligomenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS. Mutation of which of the following genes can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Mutation of the CYP21 gene can cause polycystic ovarian syndrome.

The gene for 21-hydroxylase (CYP21) is located in the short arm of chromosome 6. Heterozygosity of the gene has been linked to the development of PCOS. Defects in this gene also lead to congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

PCOS and PCOD are two different diseases. In PCOD, the ovaries begin to release immature eggs, resulting in hormonal imbalances and enlarged ovaries, whereas in PCOS, it is an endocrine disorder that causes the ovaries to create excess androgens, making the eggs prone to cyst formation. However, unlike with PCOD, these cysts will not be expelled and will instead accumulate in the ovaries.

questions.text: A teenage girl presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawline and upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The most common cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen-dependent sexual hair or male distribution of hair in female patients. PCOS accounts for 70-80% of the cases of hirsutism, which typically begins in late adolescence or the early 20s.

Idiopathic hirsutism is the second most frequent cause. The most common rapid onset of hirsutism in young females is a testosterone-producing tumour like granulosa cell or Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours.

Other less common causes of hirsutism include:

  • Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Tumours of the ovary and adrenal gland
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • Drug-induced

Virilisation: Characterized by more extensive androgen-induced changes than hirsutism alone. It has the following features:

  • Acne
  • Increased oily skin
  • Temporal balding
  • Clitoromegaly
  • Deepening of the voice
  • Development of male muscular pattern and body habitus
  • Atrophy of breasts

Hypertrichosis: Excessive growth of non-sexual hair.

questions.text: A mother brought her 15-year-old daughter to the OPD with concerns of excessive growth of coarse hair over her face and chest. Which scoring system is used to clinically grade this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used to clinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism.

Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of them scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is ≥8. Moderate to severe hirsutism is present if the score is ≥15.

Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites, viz., forearm, and legs.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Rotterdam criteria used to diagnose?
questions.solution:
The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS. 

ESHRE/ASRM or Rotterdam criteria (2003):

Any two out of these three must be present-

  • Clinical/ Biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria used for diagnosing PCOS:

  • National Institute of Health (NIH) criteria (1990)
    • To include both
      • Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism
      • Oligo/anovulation
  • Androgen excess and PCOS society(AE-PCOS) criteria:
    • To include both:
      • Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism
      • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

Option A: Meig's syndrome refers to ascites and pleural effusions that accompany a benign ovarian tumor.

Option B: Asherman's syndrome refers to the formation of intrauterine synechiae, usually following endometrial destructive procedures like curettage or ablation.

Option C: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome is characterised by congenital absence of vagina, primary amenorrhoea, rudimentary cornua uteri and morphologically normal ovaries and Fallopian tubes situated on the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text: An adolescent girl was brought by her mother to the clinic with complaints of irregular periods and acne. A USG scan was performed which showed the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the neck­lace appearance on ultrasound are suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease.

The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when ≥12 follicles were seen per ovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volume should be >10 ml. Due to improvement in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for follicle number has now been raised to 20 per ovary.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who presented with complaints of irregular cycles and weight gain was diagnosed with PCOS. This condition is characterised by multiple ovarian cysts that are less than _____ in size.
questions.solution:
PCOS is characterised by multiple small ovarian cysts, each less than 1 cm in size.

Sonographic findings seen in PCOS are:

  • ≥ 12 small cysts of 2 to 9 mm in diameter.
  • Increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both.

A single ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS. However, this criteria does not apply to women taking combined oral contraceptive pills.

Note: In settings with improved sonographic imaging resolution, a follicle number ≥ 20 cysts per ovary can be considered significant for PCOS.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady presented to your clinics with lesions as shown in the below images. Which of the following is a false statement regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmented areas in the given image are acanthosis nigricans and this is associated with hyperinsulinemia. This skin condition is thought to be a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance.

Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in the intertriginous areas. It has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck, axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin. 

The pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans is linked to growth factor levels and insulin-mediated activation of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) on keratinocytes and increased growth factor levels.

Acanthosis nigricans is usually seen in people younger than 40 years of age and is associated with the following disorders:

  • Obesity
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Acromegaly
  • Polycystic ovary disease
  • Insulin-resistant diabetes
  • Cushing’s disease
  • Addison’s disease
  • Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas.

The treatment for acanthosis nigricans is directed towards the management of the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with hirsutism. After further evaluation, a diagnosis of HAIR-AN syndrome was made. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
HAIR-AN syndrome is not characterized by mild hyperandrogenism but marked hyperandrogenism (HA). It also includes insulin resistance (IR) and acanthosis nigricans (AN).

HAIR-AN syndrome and ovarian hyperthecosis are exaggerated phenotypes of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Women affected by HAIR-AN syndrome often present with symptoms of severe hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne) and may occasionally display signs of virilization like clitoromegaly, temporal balding and voice deepening.

Ovarian hyperthecosis is a rare condition characterized by nests of luteinized theca cells distributed throughout the ovarian stroma.

questions.text: A young lady being evaluated for infertility is diagnosed to have PCOS. Which of the following lab findings would you not expect to see in her?
questions.solution:
A depressed HDL level and elevated total cholesterol:HDL ratios are seen in patients with PCOS.

The following are associated with PCOS: 

  • Insulin resistance
  • Impaired glucose tolerance and type 2 diabetes mellitus 
  • Dyslipidemia: Increased LDL and triglyceride levels, elevated total cholesterol levels:HDL ratios. 
  • Infertility/subfertility
  • A three-fold increased risk of endometrial cancer
  • Mild elevations in testosterone levels <200 ng/dL

Normal range of testosterone in women is 20-70 ng/dL. A mild elevation in testosterone is consistent with the diagnosis of PCOS. However, values > 200 ng/dL may suggest an ovarian tumour and warrant pelvic sonography.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A teenage girl who recently got diagnosed with PCOS presented with skin lesions on her forehead as shown in the image below. On examination, hirsutism was also noted. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are acne. The drugs used to treat acne and hirsutism in a patient with PCOS are OCPs with cyproterone acetate.

The first step in the management of PCOS is weight reduction. OCPs are the drugs of choice for regularisation of cycles. They are also the drugs of choice for hirsutism and acne. OCPs used for PCOS should contain a 3rd/4th generation progestagen like cyproterone acetate. OCPs induce regular menstrual cycles, lower androgen levels and causes thinning of the endometrium.

Insulin sensitizers like metformin have been found to improve metabolic and gynecologic issues. It acts by reducing the insulin level and reducing hepatic production of glucose (liver neoglycolysis). Other benefits of metformin include improvement in fertility rate and reduction of the total and free testosterone levels. It also increases levels of sex hormone-binding globulin. Metformin is contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease.

Treatment of infertility associated with PCOS is done using ovulation-inducing drugs like letrozole and clomiphene citrate. If medical management fails, surgical options like laparoscopic ovarian drilling can be considered.

Note: 

FOGSI, in 2024, has replaced Letrozole as the first-line drug for induction of ovulation in patients with PCOS. However, the FDA approval for the same is still pending.

 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years in spite of regular intercourse. She has recently been diagnosed with PCOS. Which of the following is the FDA approved medication that you could recommend to her?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene is an FDA approved drug used for the treatment of infertility associated with PCOS.

Clomiphene induces ovulation in 80% of the cases and 40–50% patients conceive. However, abortions are common due to luteal phase defects. Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs in <1% cases. Co-administration with dexamethasone leads to better outcomes. In resistant case, tamoxifen 20–40 mg daily for 5 days should be tried.

Currently, letrozole has proven to be more effective in ovarian infertility in obese women but its use in such cases is pending FDA approval.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with PCOS, which of the following is not an indication for surgical management?
questions.solution:
Surgical management is indicated in all the above conditions except for morbid obesity.

Indications of surgery in PCOS include:

  • Failed medical therapy
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation
  • Infertility
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Surgery comprises of laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine milieu and improves fertility for a year or so. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. The formation of adhesions can be reduced by hydrofloatation.

The advantages of surgery are as follows: 

  • Tubal testing with chromotubation can be performed simultaneously
  • Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be looked for
  • One-time treatment
  • Intense and prolonged monitoring for side effects is not required
  • Cost-effective compared to IVF
  • Reduces androgen and LH production
  • Following surgery, single ovulation occurs with drugs, and hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies are avoided
  • Ovulation occurs in 80–90% and pregnancy in 60–70%

The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:

  • It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy
  • Adhesions may form postoperatively
  • If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human menopausal gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing enlarged ovaries with multiple large cysts along with the history of treatment for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin suggests the diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). 

Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It is used to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a condition associated with ovarian enlargement due to exogenous gonadotropin therapy. Symptoms include abdominal pain, distention, ascites, gastrointestinal problems, respiratory compromise, oliguria, and thromboembolism. It can occur during ovulation induction or in early pregnancies conceived through exogenous ovarian stimulation. 

Predisposing factors for OHSS include multi-follicular ovaries (such as in PCOS), young age, high estradiol levels during ovulation induction, and pregnancy.

Vasoactive substances produced by the corpus luteum, such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and angiotensin II, are believed to contribute to enhanced capillary permeability, resulting in the loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity and hemoconcentration. 

Sonographic examination reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts and ascites. 

Maintaining fluid balance with isotonic fluids like normal saline is crucial. Strategies to prevent OHSS during exogenous ovulation include reducing follicular stimulation (low FSH dose), coasting (withholding FSH administration one or more days prior to the hCG trigger), prophylactic volume expanders, and substituting hCG for FSH towards the end of ovarian stimulation.

Other options:

Option B: Theca lutein cysts are a rare form of follicular cysts characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of the theca interna layer. Both ovaries are enlarged and cystic. This condition is commonly associated with gestational trophoblastic disease, multifetal gestation, and placentomegaly. 

Option C: Polycystic ovarian syndrome shows 12 or more small follicles each 2-9 mm in size placed peripherally (necklace pattern) (shown below). The patient presents with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, etc.

questions.text: A 21-year-old nulliparous woman presented with galactorrhoea and breast engorgement. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in its pathophysiology
Prolactin levels more than 25 ng/ml cause this condition
All patients with hyperprolactinemia present with galactorrhoea
The drug of choice is Cabergoline

questions.solution:
All patients with hyperprolactinaemia do not present with galactorrhoea.

Galactorrhoea is the secretion of milky fluid from the nipple which is unrelated to childbirth. Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in the pathophysiology of amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. Majority of women (80%) with high prolactin levels present with galactorrhoea. However, some hyperprolactinemic women may not have this symptom.

Normal prolactin level is 25 ng/mL and levels more than this can cause galactorrhoea. Levels up to 100 ng/mL occur in hyperprolactinaemia but prolactin level over 100 ng/mL is seen in pituitary tumours.

Galactorrhoea is caused by pituitary adenoma and hyperprolactinemia. The condition is associated with amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea and infertility. The drug of choice for this condition is cabergoline.
